prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Company Manuals and Documents Containing Confidential Information

para.paratext: A review of relevant company policies related to confidential information should be conducted with an employee at the time he or she begins employment. Certainly the fact that the employee will obtain confidential information should be addressed at the outset of the relationship.

Where a company manual or other sensitive information is distributed to employees in connection with their employment duties, signed acknowledgments of receipt should be obtained by the company. In addition, company manuals can be numbered to allow the employer to easily account for all copies. The employer should ensure that all confidential manuals or documents are returned prior to an employee's departure from employment. At that time, the employee should also sign an acknowledgment stating that he or she has returned all confidential documents and information, including copies, prior to departure.

During employment, when sensitive documents are removed from secure areas, a log book should be maintained to ensure proper monitoring and return. In addition, any document or binder containing confidential material should be marked as such and stamped with appropriate phrases such as “Strictly Confidential” and “Do Not Copy”.
Support staff who come into contact with confidential information should be made aware of their duties and of any relevant business policies.
Finally, it should be clear to all individuals in receipt of sensitive information that such information must not be discussed in public areas such as elevators or reception areas.
